snippet: The case against five security guards in the 2007 killings of 17 people in Baghdad once seemed clear-cut. But it has been undermined by the prosecution’s own mistakes.
abstract: Case against five former Blackwater contractors involved in 2007 killings of 17 people in Baghdad, once seemingly clear-cut, has been repeatedly undermined by prosecution's own mistakes; prosecutors are trying to hold together what is left, bringing new first-degree murder charge against Nicholas A Slatten, who was allowed to walk free after statute of limitations expired; case against three remaining guards is also set to go to trial and will likely bring renewed focus to one of Iraq war's most notorious episodes.
lead_paragraph: The case against five security guards in the 2007 killings of 17 people in Baghdad once seemed clear-cut. But it has been undermined by the prosecution’s own mistakes.

headline.main: Trying to Salvage Remains of Blackwater Case
headline.print_headline: Trying to Salvage Remains of Blackwater Case
